Pre-Game Insights: Both teams on the ropes ahead of heavyweight contest
England fear another knockouts blow as South Africa look to put Netherlands defeat to one side
Ben Stokes is all set to play against South Africa
England seek Mumbai magic in pursuit of World Cup lift-off
Siya Kolisi, South Africa's World Cup-winning captain, stated his 'belief' and 'trust' in his cricketing counterparts

Ben Stokes, the team's 'spiritual leader' in the words of head coach Matthew Mott, has iced up his painfully popped hip muscle and will creak his way back into the fray to shore up a team that's running out of wriggle room
Quinton de Kock has started this World Cup in a rare old mood, having confirmed before the tournament that this will be his ODI swansong
Miscellaneous Highlights: Mumbai's had to wait two weeks to get into the World Cup spirit, but the first track of the tournament will surely offer runs in abundance
In a historically close-fought ODI rivalry, South Africa edge the head-to-head, with 33 wins from 64 completed matches, compared to England's 30
It's been similarly closely fought in World Cup clashes, with England this time winning the head-to-head 4-3, including victories in each of their last two meetings, in 2019 and in 2011
Joe Root needs 72 runs to reach 1000 in his World Cup career, across three tournaments and 21 matches
Jos Buttler needs 105 runs to reach 5000 in ODIs
It's 25 years since England and South Africa last played international cricket and rugby on the same day
Others: England: 1 Jonny Bairstow, 2 Dawid Malan, 3 Joe Root, 4 Ben Stokes, 5 Jos Buttler (capt/wk), 6 Harry Brook, 7 Chris Woakes/Gus Atkinson, 8 David Willey, 9 Adil Rashid, 10 Mark Wood, 11 Reece Topley

South Africa (probable): 1 Quinton de Kock (wk), 2 Temba Bavuma (capt), 3 Rassie van der Dussen, 4 Aiden Markram, 5 David Miller, 6 Heinrich Klaasen, 7 Marco Jansen, 8 Kagiso Rabada, 9 Keshav Maharaj, 10 Lungi Ngidi, 11 Tabraiz Shamsi/Gerald Coetzee
